object.course_desc: Elementary study of the language required for studying a religious tradition.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1902 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): Major/Minor in Religion or permission of the department.
Tutorial two hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: Major/Minor in Religion or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: A survey of the history, beliefs and practices of these major religious traditions.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1000.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: A survey of the history, beliefs, and practices of South and East Asian religious traditions, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Daoism, Confucianism, and Shinto.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1715, RELI 1716.
Lecture three hours per week.

object.course_desc: The variety of religious experiences and their interpretations: myth, literature, art and religious doctrine. Topics include time, self, the other, journey and wisdom. Examples ranging from shamanistic experience to the abstractions of Buddhist philosophy.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1205, RELI 1206, RELI 1402, and RELI 2002.
Prerequisite(s): restricted to students registered in the Bachelor of Humanities & Religion program.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: restricted to students registered in the Bachelor of Humanities & Religion program.

object.course_desc: An introduction to major issues in the study of religion in global contexts, drawing on historical and contemporary examples.
object.course_extra_details: Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Intermediate study of the language required for studying a religious tradition. Restricted to students registered in a Religion program.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2902 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): RELI 1902 or RELI1010 or permission of the department.
Tutorial two hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI 1902 or RELI1010 or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: The history of Judaism and the Jewish people from the Second Temple until the present day. The organization, basic beliefs, social and ethical practices of the Jews and Judaism.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1008 and RELI 2508.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Introduces the Hebrew Bible within historical and religious frameworks.  All texts are in English.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3505C taught in 2007-2008.
Prerequisite(s): RELI1710 or RELI 1000 or RELI2110 or RELI 2508 or permission of the department.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI1710 or RELI 1000 or RELI2110 or RELI 2508 or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: An introduction to the history, beliefs, traditions, practices, and diversity of Christianity from its beginnings to the present day.
object.course_extra_details: Lecture three hours per week.

object.course_desc: Introduction to the critical study of the writings of the New Testament with discussion of their Hellenistic and Jewish background, the historical Jesus, Paul and his letters, and historical and sociological explanations for the rise of the early church and interpretation of its writings.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1003, RELI 1200 and RELI 2207.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Survey of recent and current Christian movements around the world, both by region and thematically, with emphasis on institutions and networks that connect Christian communities across national boundaries. Special consideration is given to the cultural and political capacities of such Christian communities and networks.
object.course_extra_details: Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: The study of Muslim religious tradition and investigation of its organization, basic beliefs, social and ethical principles and practices.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1009 and RELI 2509.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: An examination of the Qur'an's content, form, style, central themes, canonization, and classical and contemporary interpretive traditions.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Basic beliefs and practices of the Buddhist tradition and a brief survey of its development and transformations in India, Sri Lanka, Southeast Asia, Tibet, China and Japan.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1006 and RELI 2106.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Basic beliefs, practices, and social structures of the Hindu tradition as reflected in Hindu scriptures, myths and symbols, and philosophical schools.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1005 and RELI 2005.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Myths and symbols of the Indian tradition expressed in Hindu and Buddhist art. Hindu theories of beauty and the interface of the arts with the spiritual traditions of India.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2005 (if taken before 2007-2008) and RELI 2008.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: An exploration of issues related to gender and religion in historical and contemporary contexts.
object.course_extra_details: Lectures three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Survey of the origins, development, and diffusion of Chinese religious traditions, including Confucianism, Daoism, Chinese Buddhism and popular religion(s).
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: The early history, literature and ideas of Judaism, Christianity and Islam from 200 BCE to 750 CE.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2208.
Prerequisite(s): restricted to students in the Bachelor of Humanities & Religion program.
Lecture three hours per week.
object.course_prerequisites: restricted to students in the Bachelor of Humanities & Religion program.

object.course_desc: An exploration of love as expressed in religious literatures and religious practices.
object.course_extra_details: Lectures three hours a week.

object.course_desc: An historical survey emphasizing the interactions of various religious traditions in Canada, including indigenous religions, Christian missionary and colonial traditions, immigrant and global diaspora religions.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2307 Section A (2007-2008).
Lectures three hours a week.

object.course_desc: An historical and functional study of mystical experiences in their religious contexts, relying on examples from selected traditions such as the Christian, Buddhist, Hindu, Jewish and Muslim.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2300.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Religions of Inuit, First Nations and Métis peoples, past and present. Considerations include concepts of tradition, syncretism and “creative ritual.” Primary sources may include textual, visual and oral materials. Course may include fieldwork, as well as in-class presentations by community elders.
object.course_extra_details: Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: The meaning of death and afterlife in some religious traditions and secular philosophies with emphasis on the Hindu teaching of the immortal soul; the Hebraic idea of collective survival; the Christian doctrine of resurrection of the body; the Buddhist conception of no-soul and nirvana.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2308.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: A study of religion in ancient Greece.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as CLCV2103.
Precludes additional credit for CLCV 2102, RELI 2734, RELI 2102.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Cross-cultural survey of religious institutions, focusing on theories and methodologies in the study of religion. Topics may include myth, totemism, cults, ritual, belief systems, altered states of consciousness, new religious and/or new age movements and the relationship of religion with other social institutions and processes.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Also listed as ANTH2550.
Lectures and workshop three hours a week.

object.course_desc: A study of religion in ancient Rome.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as CLCV2104.
Precludes additional credit for CLCV 2102 and RELI 2734 and RELI 2102.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: A study of philosophical issues arising from religion. Topics may include: arguments for and against the existence of God, religious experience, death and the afterlife, miracles, God and evil, the relationship between religion and science, and the relationship between religion and ethics.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as PHIL2601.
Prerequisite(s): a course in philosophy or second-year standing.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: a course in philosophy or second-year standing.

object.course_desc: In this Inquiry course, students will be introduced to a specific topic in Religious Studies (e.g., ritual, narrative, space) and develop a research project related to it. Focus on fostering intellectual curiosity and developing practical skills of reading, writing and research fundamentals.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2002 (no longer offered), RELI 1205 (no longer offered), RELI 1402 (no longer offered), and RELI 1730 (no longer offered).
Seminar three hours per week.

object.course_desc: An examination of the basic beliefs, practices, and social structures of the Sikh tradition as reflected in Sikh scriptures, history and philosophical schools.
object.course_extra_details: Lecture three hours a week

object.course_desc: This course illuminates a recent category of “World Religions” by examining cases from all five continents, as well as in diaspora (e.g., Brazilian Candomblé, Roma/Sinti religion). Considerations include the study of minority religions, religion in oral cultures, myth & ritual studies, colonialism, globalization.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 1720 (no longer offered).
Lecture three hours per week.

object.course_desc: Examination of interactions between religion and popular culture in the form of music, film, video games, literature, and other media. Topic and focus will vary year to year; please check departmental website for information. May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Lecture three hours per week.

object.course_desc: Attitudes in the major world religions to nature and the environment and recent responses by religious traditions to ecological degradation and crisis. Includes examination of religious sensibilities expressed in environmentalism.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3710.
Lecture three hours per week.

object.course_desc: Content of this course may vary from year to year.  Please check departmental website for information on the topic.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for repeated topics.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: This course examines some aspects of the intersection between religion(s) and public life, broadly construed, including social, economic, political, institutional aspects, either in the contemporary world or focused on a particular historical period.
object.course_extra_details: Seminar three hours per week.

object.course_desc: Advanced study of the language required for studying a religious tradition.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3902 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): RELI 2902 (no longer offered) or RELI2010 or permission of the department.
Tutorial two hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI 2902 (no longer offered) or RELI2010 or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: Discussion of the embodiment of religious ideas in life, law, and practice, for example in food consumption, gender ideologies, sexuality, adornment, and death rituals. Topic will vary year to year; please check departmental website for information. May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3130 (no longer offered), RELI 3131 (no longer offered), RELI 3331 (no longer offered), RELI 3734 (no longer offered).
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Introduction to the historical and religious dimensions of the Holocaust.  The foundations, perpetration and consequences of the Nazi Final Solution through primary sources including survivor testimony will be examined.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as HIST3714.
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing or permission of the department.
 Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: A history of the Protestant and Catholic Reformations of the sixteenth century, with emphasis on the theological disputes of the protagonists and the impact of these disputes on the social, political and cultural developments of the era.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as HIST3708.
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3708 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): 0.5 credit at the 2000-level in HIST or third-year standing.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: 0.5 credit at the 2000-level in HIST or third-year standing.

object.course_desc: This course examines the development of Christian practices and teachings from late antiquity to early modernity, with a special emphasis on their historical diversity and the complex dynamics of church formation. Students should expect to read (in English) both primary and secondary sources.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2210 (no longer offered), RELI 2225 (no longer offered).
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Developments in Christian practices and teachings over the early modern and modern periods, especially in relation to social changes commonly associated with modernity including: urbanization, state formation, industrialization, colonization, the development of capitalist economies.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2210 (no longer offered), RELI 2226 (no longer offered).
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: A study of the historical records of the life of Jesus, the methods used to interpret them, and the resulting images of Jesus.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2205, RELI 3208 and RELI 3105.
Prerequisite(s): RELI 2207 or RELI2220 or permission of the department.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI 2207 or RELI2220 or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: The social, religious, and historical context of Paul, the communities he founded, and the letters he wrote to them.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3300 and RELI 3106.
Prerequisite(s): RELI 2207 or RELI2220 or permission of the department.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI 2207 or RELI2220 or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: An historical survey of key Christian thought and practices at the individual and collective level.  Topics may include self-discipline, body discipline, monastic discipline, church discipline and social discipline.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3302 Section "A" taught in 2007-2008.
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing or permission of the department.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: The development of some protestant Christianities in relation to material factors, such as colonialism, industrial or consumer capitalism, imperialism, and in relation to major ideological trends, such as nationalism, economic or political liberalism and atheism.
object.course_extra_details: Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: An examination of the integral role music plays in religion and sacred ritual in different world cultures and religions. Through various case studies, the course broadly considers how sacred soundscapes shape people’s worldviews, identities, and experiences within and outside of their communities.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as MUSI3301.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: An introduction to the main practical and theoretical dimensions of Islam's mystical tradition as seen through the life and work of its key representatives.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): RELI2710 or RELI2713 or permission of the department.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI2710 or RELI2713 or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: Studies in issues related to magic, witchcraft and/or the occult in various historical, religious, and cultural contexts.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing, or 0.5 credit in RELI, or permission of the department.
Lectures 3 hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing, or 0.5 credit in RELI, or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: Overview of the life and teaching of the Prophet Muhammad, and the most salient motifs and features of Muslim devotion to him.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 2340.
Prerequisite(s): RELI1710 or RELI2310 or permission of the department.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI1710 or RELI2310 or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: A focus on post-Qur'anic Islamic literature and interpretive traditions (e.g. tafsir, hadith); texts and topics will vary from year to year;  please check departmental website for information. May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): RELI2310 or RELI2330.
Lecture three hours per week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI2310 or RELI2330.

object.course_desc: An exploration of the development of early Buddhist philosophy, psychology, religious texts, and practices.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3215.
Prerequisite(s): RELI 2106 or RELI2410 or permission of the department.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI 2106 or RELI2410 or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: The rise of the Mahayana and the dissemination and development of Buddhist thought and practice outside of India.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3217.
Prerequisite(s): RELI 2106 or RELI2410 or permission of the department.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: RELI 2106 or RELI2410 or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: A historical survey of Hinduism from the Vedic era to the development of devotional Hinduism.  Vedic religion and developments in early Hindu Philosophy and sectarian Hinduism.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3015.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: A survey of major developments in Hinduism since the period of colonial British rule.  The development of “reform” Hinduism in the 18th and 19th centuries, and the emergence of Hindu nationalist movements in the 20th century.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for RELI 3007.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: A thematic course that examines putative cases of “religion and violence” from a range of world traditions, but also interrogates aspects of the “religion and violence” rubric itself.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing or permission of the department.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: A study of period or theme in the art and archaeology of Ancient Greece. Topics may vary from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as ARTH3102, CLCV3306.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit required to repeat.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit required to repeat.

object.course_desc: A study of a period or theme in the art and archaeology of the ancient Romans. Topics may vary from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as ARTH3105, CLCV3307.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit required to repeat.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing or permission of the unit. Permission of the unit required to repeat.

object.course_desc: Examination of reflection on the nature and origin of religion from the ancient world up to key figures and founders of the discipline of the systematic, critical, and scientific study of religion in the nineteenth and early twentieth century.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lecture three hours per week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Content of this course may vary from year to year.  Please check departmental website for information on the topic.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for repeated topics.
Lecture three hours a week.

object.course_desc: This travel course explores religion in its historical and/or contemporary contexts in a particular geographic locale.  Travel destinations, religious traditions studied, course content, and themes vary from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third year standing and 1.0 credit of study in the area related to the year's topic religion, and permission of the department. Permission of the department is required to repeat this course.
Hours to be arranged. Costs associated with the course are borne by the student.
object.course_prerequisites: third year standing and 1.0 credit of study in the area related to the year's topic religion, and permission of the department. Permission of the department is required to repeat this course.

object.course_desc: Legal, theoretical, and theological interconnections between religion and human rights. Evaluation of concepts including religious freedom, secularism, public sphere, accommodation and neutrality. Examination of religion and culture, interdependence of legal and religious perspectives, boundaries of religion and state, and religious compulsion. Use of case studie.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as HUMR 4602, RELI4602.
Prerequisite(s): LAWS2908, LAWS3602, and fourth-year Honours standing.
Seminar
object.course_prerequisites: LAWS2908, LAWS3602, and fourth-year Honours standing.

object.course_desc: This course engages with the real world implications of late twentieth and twenty-first century scholarship on religion with a focus on applied learning and developing employable skills that facilitate transition from academia to a career.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for RELI3301, RELI 4301, RELI 4740 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.
Seminar three hours per week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: A tutorial on a topic in religious studies. Contents of the tutorial to be arranged with the supervising faculty member.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: Content of this course may vary from year to year.  Please consult the departmental website for information on the topic.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as RELI5850, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminar three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: Critical reflection on the theme of religion and public life as evidenced in today's Ottawa. Experiential learning via a 30-hour placement, contextualized through readings and in-class sessions (in weeks 3, 6, 12), and culminating in a reflective final project.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in BA Honours or BA Combined Honours Religion program, and 10.0 Major CGPA, and 1.0 credit in the area in which the practicum will take place, and permission of the Department.
Field placement with weekly synchronous check-ins.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in BA Honours or BA Combined Honours Religion program, and 10.0 Major CGPA, and 1.0 credit in the area in which the practicum will take place, and permission of the Department.

object.course_desc: Honours research paper (approx. 40 pages) is due on the last day of winter term classes. Written proposal due to the Proposal Board on the first day of fall term classes.  Please consult department document for full requirements and information.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for RELI 4908 and RELI 4909.
Prerequisite(s): 10.0 CGPA and fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.
object.course_prerequisites: 10.0 CGPA and fourth-year standing in the Honours B.A. Religion program, or permission of the department.
